title: Lamp with “Hanging Head Dragonfly” Shade and “Mosaic and Turtleback” Base

thumbnail.alt_text: Lamp with stained glass shade featuring dragonflies and shades of green, purple, brown.

artist_display:
Design attributed to Clara Pierce Wolcott Driscoll
American, 1861–1944
Made by Tiffany Studios
American, 1902–1932
Corona, New York
description: In the 1890s Louis Comfort Tiffany began using his opalescent Favrile glass to produce lamps, the decorative form for which he would become most famous. As the artistic director of Tiffany Studios located in Corona, New York, he approved all patterns but created relatively few lamps himself. Clara Driscoll, head of the Women’s Glass Cutting Department, was likely responsible for this shade and base. Driscoll began working for Tiffany in 1888, and she designed the majority of the firm’s lamps before she left the company in 1908 or 1909. Driscoll created at least eight dragonfly shades. This example is distinguished by its large size, glass cabochons, and the placement of insects’ bodies along the lower edge. While Tiffany Studios mass-produced these shades and bases, the firm varied the color scheme of each object to heighten the sense of handcraftsmanship. This daring design became one of Tiffany’s most popular and was made through 1924.
inscriptions:
Shade model 1507 stamped: TIFFANY STUDIOS NEW YORK 1507
Base model 355 impressed: TIFFANY STUDIOS NEW YORK 5858
TIFFANY STUDIOS NEW YORK

Annual Report (Art Institute of Chicago, 2005–2006), 22 (ill. p. 18).

Ellen E. Roberts, "Hanging Head Dragonfly Shade on Mosaic and Turtleback Base," Notable Acquisitions at the Art Institute of Chicago, Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies, 34, 1 (2008), 16–17.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Apostles of Beauty: Arts and Crafts from Britain to Chicago, Nov. 7, 2009–Jan. 31, 2010, cat. 155.
provenance_text: Jeffrey Thier, Buffalo, New York; sold to D. Leonard and Gerry Trent, New York, New York, c. 1981. Joel Schur, Greenwich, CT; sold, Christie's New York, "Important Art Nouveau, The Joel Schur Collection," December 14, 1985, lot 18. Gary Wexler; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.
